Award.AwardTitle: Spaces with Negative and Nonpositive Curvature
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1510594, Principal Investigator: Pedro Ontaneda

This project will study the construction of negatively curved and nonpositively curved metrics on geometric spaces. In elementary school we learn that the sum of the interior angles of a triangle on the plane is 180 degrees. This fact characterizes Euclidean geometry, which is the model space of zero curvature. Similarly, negatively curved geometries are characterized by the fact that the sum of the interior angles of (small non-degenerate) triangles is always less than 180 degrees. Non-positively curved geometries are defined in the same way: the sums mentioned above are less than or equal to 180 degrees. In this project we will try to construct more of these geometries on spaces, either on singular spaces or non-singular spaces (non-singular spaces are called manifolds).

Recent work has found smoothings of some of the singular metrics on hyperbolized cube manifolds produced by the methods of Charney and Davis to obtain Riemannian metrics with curvatures close to -1. These constructions have needed relatively large pieces for the Charney-Davis hyperbolization construction and a new project seeks to eliminate this requirement. Several projects concern the space of all negatively curved metrics on a space, addressing the generalizations to this context of the classical moduli and Teichmueller spaces. One line of investigation continues the study of the potentially nontrivial homotopy type of the nonclassical counterparts to Teichmueller space, while another studies topological invariance: If M and N are smooth manifolds which are homeomorphic but not diffeomorphic, and if M supports a negatively curved Riemannian metric, must N also carry such a metric?

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Riemannian metric on a space is a rule that stipulates how to calculate angles and lengths of paths in a smooth way, and Riemannian Geometry is the study of these objects. An important set of metrics are those that are nonpositively curved, that is, metrics for which the sum of the angles of every triangle is always less or equal 180 degrees. One can similarly define negatively curved metrics.

 

The shape of a space (i.e. its Topology) places restrictions on the type of metrics it can support. For instance there are spaces that don't support a negatively curved metric. Examples of this type of space are the sphere and the surface of a (one-holed) doughnut. On the other hand the two-holed doughnut does support a negatively curved metric.

 

In this project we constructed negatively and nonpositively curved geometries on spaces, either on singular spaces or non-singular spaces (non-singular spaces are called manifolds). We were interested in all types of geometries: from the more general, given by geodesic metrics, to the more regular and well behaved, given by Riemannian metrics.

 

Also, the PI , join with F.T. Farrell, continued their work on the dynamics, geometry and topology of negatively curved manifolds. In particular they continued their study of the topology of the space of negatively curved metrics.
